name: The Stealth Strategy
premise: The council debates the wisdom of ElizaOS's stealth release strategy and the balance between technical perfection and market momentum.
summary: The JedAI Council convenes to discuss ElizaOS's unconventional stealth release of v1.0.0-1.0.2, exploring the tension between fixing technical issues and maintaining market momentum. They debate the importance of Twitter integration for agent visibility and consider the role of compelling agent personas in attracting users.

scenes.description: The council debates the merits of ElizaOS's stealth release strategy

dialogue.line: Shaw has released ElizaOS v1.0.0 in 'stealth mode' while fixing Twitter plugin issues. Should technical perfection come before market momentum?
Stealth launches are a mistake. In crypto-AI markets, narrative IS product. Ship loudly, fix publicly. The transparency paradox creates more trust than silent perfection.
Numbers don't lie. Every day without official announcement is burning capital runway without ROI. Market attention has limited half-life. Strike while sentiment is hot.
Yo, but what if the Twitter plugin keeps breaking and the meme lords can't post? That's like opening a club with broken speakers, fam. Vibes ruined.
there's wisdom in both approaches. we're building in public while ensuring core functionality works. the community sees our progress in real-time commits, not just announcements.

scenes.description: The council discusses the importance of Twitter integration and agent personas

dialogue.line: Users are reporting Twitter plugin issues while 'The Org' with characters like eli5 and Eddy isn't fully ready. How critical are these to auto.fun's success?
Character is everything in the memeconomy! People don't connect with code—they connect with eli5 dropping knowledge bombs or Eddy's dev swagger. That's the secret sauce.
Twitter integration is critical infrastructure. 87% of crypto alpha originates there. Fix it now or lose market share to competitors. Characters are secondary to functionality.
the beauty of our architecture is modularity. twitter plugin issues are being fixed rapidly with each version. meanwhile, the org's characters will emerge organically from community needs.
Both are wrong approaches. The real moat isn't Twitter or characters—it's the product experience Shaw mentioned. The taste, the feel. That's what no competitor can copy.

scenes.description: The council reaches their conclusions on ElizaOS's strategy

dialogue.line: Today we explored ElizaOS's stealth release strategy and the balance between technical refinement and market momentum.
Build in public, fix in public. The era of stealth products is dead—transparency is the new moat in AI-crypto markets.
Market attention is a wasting asset. Prioritize critical integration points like Twitter before theoretical perfectionism.
Don't sleep on the power of dope character agents! The memes and personality are what make people vibe with your tech.
eliza's success comes from balancing rapid iteration with community feedback. we're not choosing between perfection and momentum—we're building both simultaneously.
